attributes.name: ai_familiarity
attributes.description: Self-reported familiarity with artificial intelligence concepts and tools (None, Basic, Intermediate, Advanced, Expert).

attributes.name: ai_usage_frequency
attributes.description: How often the person uses AI-powered tools in daily life (Never, Rarely, Monthly, Weekly, Daily).

attributes.name: tech_sector_employment
attributes.description: Whether the person works in the technology industry or a closely adjacent STEM field.

attributes.name: sci_fi_consumption
attributes.description: Frequency of consuming science fiction media (books, films, TV) that shapes mental models of AI (Never, Rarely, Sometimes, Often, Very Often).

attributes.name: asi_initial_reaction
attributes.description: Person's dominant initial emotional reaction upon hearing the ASI announcement (Excited, Fearful, Skeptical, Indifferent, Mixed).

attributes.name: ai_safety_concern_level
attributes.description: Degree of concern about existential or societal risks from advanced AI systems (0–1 scale, 0 = no concern, 1 = extreme concern).

attributes.name: openai_brand_familiarity
attributes.description: Level of prior awareness and familiarity with OpenAI as a company (Never heard of it, Vaguely aware, Somewhat familiar, Very familiar).

attributes.name: social_influence_susceptibility
attributes.description: Tendency to update one's opinions in response to social pressure or peer discussion (0–1 scale, 0 = highly resistant, 1 = highly susceptible).

attributes.name: techno_optimism
attributes.description: General disposition toward believing technology produces positive outcomes for society (0–1 scale, 0 = techno-pessimist, 1 = techno-optimist).

attributes.name: online_discussion_propensity
attributes.description: Likelihood of actively posting, commenting, or debating the ASI news in online communities (0–1 scale).

attributes.name: job_automation_anxiety
attributes.description: Level of personal concern that AI advancement will eliminate or substantially degrade the person's own employment prospects (0–1 scale).

input.notes: Big Five traits already exist in the base population (openness, conscientiousness, extraversion, agreeableness, neuroticism) — not rediscovered here. Existing base attributes trust_in_institutions, ne...[truncated]
